Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Investigating the Presence of Bat Borne Viruses in Southeast Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bats have been implicated as the natural hosts of several lethal viruses including the ebolaviruses, marburgviruses, and henipaviruses. The outbreak of Ebola virus disease in West Africa has demonstrated that the distribution of ebolaviruses extends beyond historical geographies in Central Africa. The circulation of an ebolavirus in humans, domestic pigs, and monkeys in the Philippines and evidence of ebolavirus infection in bats from Bangladesh and China illustrates that ebolaviruses are present within the Asian continent. It is now thought that the geographic distribution of these viruses follows the geographic range of the natural host, bats. This award supports research to initiate biosurveillance to examine the footprint of ebolaviruses and marburgviruses in Southeast Asia with the long-term goal of providing needed information to support the generation of predictive virus outbreak models. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Gavin J.D. Smith, an expert in infectious disease surveillance, at the Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School in Singapore.

As part of ongoing biosurveillance projects, the laboratory of Dr. Gavin J.D. Smith has catalogued a collection of blood sera from bats native to Singapore and Southeast Asia. This collaboration with Dr. Gavin J.D. Smith offers an opportunity to screen bat sera with a Luminex test in development that is capable of simultaneous detection of antibodies specific to Ebolavirus, Marburgvirus, and Henipavirus envelope glycoproteins. The presence of antibodies in bat blood sera specific to ebolaviruses and marburgviruses indicates previous infection and potential circulation of these viruses in Southeast Asia. The use of a single multipart method to screen sera collected from bats requires less sample volume and fewer tests than traditional methods. Using virus envelope glycoprotein coated beads; sera from bats, other wildlife hosts, and livestock can be screened in a cost-effective and high throughput fashion that will be useful for future biosurveillance projects. The award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bats are regarded as the animal hosts of several of emerging viruses including viruses classified in the order Mononegavirales, which includes the virus families, Filoviridae and Paramyxoviridae. Disease outbreaks caused by these viruses have occurred in Southeast Asia, often times following an initial spillover event from the bat host. Infection with these viruses can cause an immune response that leads to the development of virus-specific antibodies. Detection of virus-specific antibodies in bats, other wildlife, domestic animals, or humans is considered evidence of having been previously exposed to the virus. Taking blood samples from bats, animal hosts of emerging viruses, and testing the blood samples for virus-specific antibodies allows us to better understand which bat species are virus hosts and to create models and predictions about the global distribution of these emerging viruses.

Our lab at the Uniformed Services University, Maryland, has developed an assay that is able to simultaneously detect the presence of virus-specific antibodies to ten virus species spanning three viral genera. In past surveillance projects, collaborators have used earlier versions of this assay to detect Paramyxoviridae-specific antibodies in fruit bats. In collaboration with Dr. Gavin J.D. Smith at the Duke-National University Singapore Graduate Medical School (Duke-NUS), Singapore, I applied our assay and tested blood samples from three bat species native to Southeast Asia for evidence of past exposure to virus species in the order Mononegavirales. We detected virus-specific antibodies in all three-bat species that were sampled. Evidence of past exposure to viruses in the order Mononegavirales will be confirmed by additional tests. In addition to testing bat blood samples, I was able to accompany members of Dr. Smith’s lab to collect additional blood samples from individual bats in Singapore.

The two months spent at Duke-NUS presented an opportunity to generate preliminary data that suggests that Southeast Asian bats have been previously exposed to some viruses in the order Mononegavirales. Furthermore, we were able to test our assay and demonstrate its usefulness for future collaborative virus surveillance projects with Dr. Smith.
